characters: TURNS THE GUN BACK INTO HIM --
THE EXPLOSION RIPS THROUGH THE TRAIN
DEREK SHOOTS COLTER TWICE IN THE CHEST.
THE FIREBALL RIPS THROUGH THE CAR
THE BOMB EXPLODES IN COLTER'S FACE WITH A HUGE AND DEAFEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLTER jolts awake. Sunlight hits his face. He blinks. A stunned beat. He's disoriented. Slowly he turns his head to one side... PASSENGERS. Filling most of the seats. Office workers on their morning commute into a city. Turning the other way, he's confronted with a window. Tre flash by, splitting the rising sunlight into a hypnotic strobe pattern. Colter looks to be thirty years old. A military buzz cut. disciplined physique, lean and spare, almost gaunt. Skin burnished by years of desert sandstorms and equatorial su His expression, prematurely aged by combat, is perpetuall wary, sometimes predatory, accustomed to trouble. Despite his military bearing, Colter wears a button down shirt and navy sports coat. On his wrist is a digital wat It reads 7:40 a.m. He swallows. A strange, creeping panic. He has no idea where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train hurls straight at us. NEW ANGLE -- Skimming alongside as the train twists and turns, sucking up track -- feet, yards, miles of it. Beneath it, the curving rails, which the rushing train ba seems to touch. They vibrate with an eerie, dulcimer HUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter hasn't moved. By his side he sees a canvas MESSENG BAG. Is that his? Tentatively, he lifts the edge of the bag to look inside. red APPLE rolls against two LIBRARY BOOKS. The bag's leat NAME TAG reads: "SEAN FENTRESS." It's not coming back to him. This whole experience is starting to freak him out. He catches the scent of something. A passenger walks by w a STEAMING CUP OF COFFEE. CHK-THOCK! Two rows back, an OVERWEIGHT MAN opens a can o soda. Sitting opposite Colter, facing him, is a WOMAN in her la twenties (CHRISTINA). In contrast to the corporate suits around her, her appearance is thrift store funky: black n polish, dark lipstick, black hair with blue streaks, a bu down blouse edged in black funeral lace with silver skull bones cufflinks. She's busy writing in a journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... ma'am? She looks up. Blank stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks out the window) Almost at Newark. Goes back to her journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Newark? A city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more of a hell hole. But Colter still doesn't understand. He gets up. Nausea slams into him. He hangs on to the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to puke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures, alarmed) Okay, bathroom's that way. Colter looks down the aisle, hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Seriously. Colter eases himself into the aisle. Totters down the len of the car until he finds the RESTROOM. The door is LOCKED. The latch reads "OCCUPIED." Bracing himself, he lurches forward into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He freezes. It's a mirror image of the first car. But no, the passengers are different. Beside him there's a small door. Thinking it's the bathro he instead opens it to find a CONDUCTOR'S COMPARTMENT. A cramped office with chairs and surveillance monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticket? A heavy-set CONDUCTOR stands in the aisle. A jangling of keys. Colter just stares at him. Dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see your ticket? The last thing on his mind. Bewildered, he searches his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to write you up then. He pulls out a citation pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this...? From inside his sports coat he pulls out a TRAIN TICKET. conductor snips his ticket and brushes past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a sec. I'm a little out of it here. Where's this train headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York. Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York? Why would he be going to New York? How can this be happening? Fear starts to grip him as the hallucination simply continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where I got on? The conductor examines his ticket again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princeton Junction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bout ten minutes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've never been to Princeton Junction. See... I don't remember waking up or buying a ticket or getting on the train or anything else. It's just a blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky you. The jaded conductor moves on. Colter is alone with his confusion. Takes a deep breath. The nausea has eased slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You're gonna figure this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering the first car again. The rows of passengers. Mus be at least forty people. As he walks back up the aisle, he looks from face to face A pale COMPUTER ENGINEER reviews some documents. A forty-something SECRETARY does a crossword puzzle. DEREK, a stock broker type, talks on his cell phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, by one o'clock, the bridge is going to be jammed... A COLLEGE STUDENT, slumped against a window, eyes shut, listens to an MP-3 player. An OLD MAN with a faded wool suit clutches a cane. A BACKPACKER, female, European, 20s, hiking boots, examin guidebook. A dowdy OFFICER MANAGER type sorts supermarket coupons in tabbed file box. An African American EXECUTIVE reads a newspaper. None of them pays any attention to Colter. A WHOOSH of AIR -- he turns to An AIR-CONDITIONING VENT. The HISS of AIR sound sinister. Like the exhalations of a creature. A SCRAPE. He looks to see A woman FILING HER NAILS. Colter cringes. Every detail, every sensory impression se heightened, near the point of overload. He reaches Christina again. Eases back in the seat across from her. She writes in her journal, ignoring him.

There's something else in his sports coat. A WALLET. He turns it over a few times, inspecting it. Pulls out a DRIVER'S LICENSE. Another man's face is in the photo. The name on the license reads: "SEAN FENTRESS." The same nam on the messenger bag. The street address on the license reads: "58 Alexander Road, Princeton Junction, New Jersey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean Fentress? Who the hell's that? And why does he have this guy's wallet? He leans forward speak with Christina again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am? She lowers her journal, annoyed. We see she hasn't been writing but DRAWING. A well-executed sketch of a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you keep calling me ma'am? How old do you think I am, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a little problem here. I'm trying not to freak out, but I think something's happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like, total memory loss. Complete. I don't know how I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you drank too much last night. So did I. Unfortunately, I remember the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not it. See... I'm a pilot. I fly helicopters in Iraq. I'm in the army. She waits for more. As if he's telling a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on a mission. Right before I woke up here I was in the middle of a mission...
Wavering. Unsure of himself. His memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you really did drink a lot last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now approaching Newark Station. Newark Station, next stop. The train begins to SLOW DOWN. A few people begin to get The platform of Newark Station slides into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These aren't my clothes. And this wallet here... He holds up the driver's license. One final attempt to convince her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this? This isn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look in the mirror, good sir. The mirror? She goes back to her sketchbook. Determined n to be interrupted again. Anxiety ripples through Colter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be happening. The train lurches to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Newark Station. Colter gets up. Through the windows, a few passengers disembark onto the platform: Derek, the Old Man, the Coll Kid and GUZMAN, a Middle Eastern man, who HURRIES past al them towards the station building.
Colter only half notices all this. He's intent on reachin the train's BATHROOM, the door of which is now OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All aboard. Doors are closing. Christina watches Colter go. Curious.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a New York bound train. Next stop, New York - Penn Station. The train begins MOVING. Colter reaches the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fluorescent light flutters on as Colter shuts the door. He's in a tiny space with prefab restroom fixtures in stainless steel. He SHOUTS in surprise. Recoils backwards. Eyes locked on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring back is SEAN FENTRESS'S FACE. Not his own. He's frozen there. Heart pounding. Seized by cosmic panic He SLAPS himself in the face. Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up! The restroom rattles and tilts with the motions of the tr obliging him to hang on. This isn't a dream. At least not one he can wake up from. The other guy's face stares back at him. Blinks when he blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warehouses go by in a blur. The train is entering New Jersey's industrial zones on the outskirts of New York Ci From her seat, Christina stares at the messenger bag whic Colter left behind. Then up at the closed restroom door.
Her hand knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You okay in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter sits on the closed toilet seat. Head buried in his hands. Scared. Desperate for it all to end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina's holding Colter's messenger bag. She talks through the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left your bag on the seat. Which is a flagrant violation of rail security, leaving a suspicious package behind and all that. I probably saved you a huge fine. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just leave it right out here for you. She places the bag beside the door. She hesitates at the door. The oddness of this situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter stares into the mirror at the stranger's face. Practically catatonic at this point. And then her voice -

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTINA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: If it'll help you remember, you've been riding this train every morning for three months. Her words rouse him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina's walking back down the aisle. The car rocks to one side as an EXPRESS TRAIN flashes by the opposite tracks, going the other way. A blur and a whoosh, and it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the verge of opening the door, Colter hears a METALLIC RATTLING. Two SCREWS are rattling around in the sink. Colter picks up a screw. Turns it over and over in his ha What are they doing in the sink? He looks UP. An overhead VENTILATION PANEL has been PRIED OPEN. Above is the darkness of a CRAWL SPACE. Something is sitting up there. From outside comes a TRAIN HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windows, a FREIGHT TRAIN is passing the other way. A moving wall of metal boxcars and liquid tankers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter looks up into the crawl space. Can't quite see the object up there. Moving carefully in the tiny space, he stands up on the toilet. Grabbing onto the ventilation panel, he WRENCHES all the way open. Then PULLS himself uncomfortably upward On tip-toes, he looks into crawl space and discovers

dialogues.speaker: A MASSIVE BOMB
dialogues.text: It's an enormous device. Several large CANNISTERS tied together, full of sloshing liquid. Barely discernible beh wires and gaffing tape is CELL PHONE -- the bomb's detona

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.
Running footsteps from outside. Commotion. An ALARM sound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuel lines explode in the other cars in a horrendous chai reaction. The fire is spectacularly bright, lighting up t windows of the rowhouse apartments facing the tracks. Nearby TREES INCINERATE, mere matchsticks amid sheets of flames. On the rowhouses, a ALUMINUM DOOR MOLDINGS begin to MELT the intense heat. One of the FREIGHT CARS, loaded down with coal, shudderin from the blast, wobbles a few yards then PITCHES OVER -- ROLLING off the rails, tipping right off the elevated tracks... It FALLS through the air and SMASHES into the middle of a traffic intersection below with a shattering force. The cascade of EXPLOSIONS continues. Large portions of BO TRAINS are ANNIHILATED, while the heat reduces the heavy- gauge steel rails back to elemental, molten ore. And then... An odd sound, like a BALLOON loosing air or MACHINERY win down as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRILLIANT WHITE. All sounds cease. For exactly 1/3 OF A SECOND, a mysterious PATTERN OF LINE appears. Like METAL RODS, maybe. RADIATING OUTWARDS. It makes no sense. An abstract pattern. Then it's gone. Many will not even see it.
Now there is only darkness. Nothingness. Seconds pass. The CLICK of an INTERCOM switching on.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Beleaguered Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're VERY CLOSE on Colter's UPSIDE DOWN face. His eyes flutter open. He's surprised to find himself alive. Consternation flashes through him as he discovers that he tightly strapped in. He now wears a military flight suit.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Captain Colter Stevens, this is Beleaguered Castle. Acknowledge transmission. The measured calm of a mission controller's voice comes o Colter's headset.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Captain Stevens, do you copy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're with Beleaguered Castle. PULL BACK, fractionally, to reveal Colter in a tight and confined CAPSULE. It bristles with sophisticated electron and ghostly glowing diodes. He's like an astronaut in an orbiter craft.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Are you functional? He tries to clear his head. He's still upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Adjusting your rotation. Very slowly, almost imperceptibly, Colter's upside-down f begins to turn and right itself.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can you report at this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Who am I talking to? More confusion. No idea how to react. Just as on the trai

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Report what you saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on a train.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... There was a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just relax, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. We're still in the tiny chamber. It's stabilized. As has Colter, but in the manner of a dangerous wild anim given a sedative. Embedded into the controls is a two inch-square VIDEO MONITOR. It shows the face of GOODWIN. He's a middle-aged communications officer. Although we know him as Goodwin, military name badge and rank insignia have been covered u He wears a headset and sits surrounded by banks of electr equipment and keyboards. He peers in at Colter, exuding t blandness of a military flight controller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standby for thread one of alpha memory pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already have that information, Captain. Now think. Recall my name. A long moment. A name floats into his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know that? I have no idea how I know your name's Goodwin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commencing memory pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Something's wrong. I was flying a mission. I was in a chopper. Then I woke up on a train. Now I'm here. Can you explain that? What unit is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with Beleaguered Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exercises will assist you. Are you ready? Just like with the train, he seems to have no choice but go along with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Memory Thread One. Listen to the following passage: "When Lily woke, she had the bed to herself. She sat up, bewildered by the strangeness of her surroundings; then memory returned, and she looked about her with a shiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cold slant of light reflected from the back wall of a neighboring building, she saw her evening dress and opera cloak lying on a tawdry heap on a chair." End of thread one. Silence. Is it Colter's turn to speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. Is this a Red Flag exercise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thread Two. Listen. I am holding the following hand of cards: Queen of spades. Four of clubs. Nine of clubs. Three of hearts. Nine of hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I repeat: Queen of spades. Four of clubs. Nine of clubs. Three of hearts. Nine of hearts. End of thread two. Beads of sweat on Colter's forehead. What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thread Three. The following is a recording of a Western Screech-Owl: A rather spooky BIRD CALL plays -- a short whistle, follo by a long trill. The call is repeated twice more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End of Thread Three. End of pattern. Acknowledge. Unexpectedly, in the back of his mind, a reply is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A... Acknowledge. End of pattern. How did he know to say that? A conditioned response?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand by to initiate pattern recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for pattern recall. The response comes to him more quickly. Like lines from a old script. Even if it still baffles him.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The five playing cards. Arrange them in order of descending values, irrespective of suit. He thinks for a moment. Focus. Play along. Maybe it will all be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen, two nines, four and a three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. The passage I read contained mention of a woman's name. What was that name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Lily. Her name was Lily. At each answer, Goodwin makes notations and adjusts gauge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. End of pattern. Goodwin leans forward to flip a switch and EVERYTHING GOE DARK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over DARKNESS, the SOUND of BACKGROUND CONVERSATION. Engineers speaking in technical jargon. Click. The unit's VIDEO MONITOR comes on again, illuminat Colter in its glow. He's still strapped into the capsule. The tiny monitor shows an out of focus view of a LAB. Lik movie camera inadvertently left on between takes. ENGINEERS wander past, oblivious. Their disjointed conversations continue at low volume. Abruptly, a MAN SMOKING A PIPE sits down in front of the camera. His graying hair is windblown and unkempt. His ey are piercing blue. He wears a track and field warm-up jacket. He looks in at us with an unsettling Cheshire-cat grin. He puffs on his pipe. Winks. Pressing a button he - Click -- shuts the whole thing off again. Sound and pictu vanish. Leaving us suspended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An indeterminate amount of time has passed. Goodwin is ba on the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please list the primary specifications of the aerial platform you've been trained to operate. Colter mulls his options. Should he talk? Keep silent? He tugs against the steel harness holding him in. A HATCH, l the kind used on submarines, seals the capsule. Goodwin's voice grows slightly louder over his headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please list the primary specifications of the aerial platform you've been trained to operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone going to tell me what's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please list the primary --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The UH-60 Blackhawk Helicopter weighs 20,250 pounds with a maximum exterior load capacity of 8,000 pounds. It has a range of 320 nautical miles and is armed with two 7.62 millimeter machine guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who bombed the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who bombed the train, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whom do you suspect bombed the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell me what the hell is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Screech-Owl song can be seen as a progression of musical notes. Did the notes go up, down or remain at the same pitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Just tell me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times was the bird call repeated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this have to do with the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times was the bird call repeated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incorrect. Who bombed the train, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who bombed the train! Colter is seething now. Had it with these games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have seventeen minutes. Use them. Find the bomber. ON SCREEN -- Goodwin leans forward to press a button and
Click. Everything goes dark. We HEAR Colter's nervous BREATHING.

dialogues.speaker: COLTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey. What's happening? The HUM of machinery starting up.

dialogues.speaker: COLTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Goodwin, what is all this? The machinery HUM changes modulation. Then gives way to a GENTLE ROCKING SENSATION. Tha-thunk. Tha-thunk. Tha-thunk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter opens his eyes... SUNLIGHT hits his face. In flickering patterns. He turns

dialogues.speaker: A TRAIN WINDOW
dialogues.text: At the passing woodland scenery. He's back on the train. Back in the same navy sports coat Across from him, Christina is at work on her sketch pad. Just like before. Other commuters all around him. Everything is exactly the same as before. Note: The remaining story will follow this "binary patter Scenes will take place either on the train or in the caps Compared to tomb-like isolation chamber he just came from the train is exploding with sensory input -- the smell of steaming coffee, the cramped proximity of other passenger the crinkle of an freshly-ironed dress shirt, the glint o buckle on a purse, the slanting sunlight, the trees out t window, bursting with summer leaves. Almost unintentionally, Colter finds himself repeating th same opening actions as last time -- checking his watch ( a.m.)... turning at the scent of passing coffee... peekin the canvas messenger bag beside him... This time, however, he takes the books out of the messeng bag. The books are stamped "NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY." He also takes out the APPLE. Sniffs it. Takes a bit. It's good. No, it's awesome. Crisp and delicious.

Is Goodwin watching him from somewhere? Not knowing what else to do, he takes a few more bites. Enjoying this small pleasure. He reaches in his sports jacket pocket and pulls out his TRAIN TICKET. CLOSE ON -- THE TICKET. It hasn't been punched yet. CHK-THOCK! The Overweight Man opens his can of soda. Just as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a goddamn simulation. Christina's pen stops sketching. She glances up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three dimensional, completely immersive scenario. Touch, taste, sound, sight and smell. A measure of relief. A way to think about all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete with pretty girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every combat simulator has one. In the middle of a fire fight a pop-up window starts playing a porno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an unusual choice for a distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a moron. Disregarding her, Colter gets up. Pursuing a new line of action. The only way he can make sense of this. He starts walking up the rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find the bomber. Find the bomber. The conductor approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ticket? Expecting this now, Colter hands over his ticket to be punched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay today, chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything out of the ordinary? The conductor frowns at him. Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take a seat, sir. Colter moves on. He looks for suspects. We've seen the faces before -- the Computer Engineer, the Secretary, the Stock Broker, the Backpacker and so on. All seems normal. He finds himself focusing on a jumble o unfiltered details -- Suits. Ties. Shoes. Skirts. Watches. Newspapers. Coffee cups. Litter. Sudden dizziness. He grabs a seatback for support. Sensor details slam into him. We go EXTREMELY CLOSE ON: The STITCHING on a leather purse. A FOUNTAIN PEN rattling in a fold-out tray. AIR CONDITIONING hissing from a vent. A CRUMPLING SOUND as the Overweight Man crushes an empty can. TAP, TAP, TAP -- the Computer Engineer tapping his foot o the floor. Faster and faster. Derek, the Wall Street Type, talks on his phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, by one o'clock, the bridge is going to be jammed... Then... the CLICK of a LOCK UNLATCHING.

The restroom door swings open. GUZMAN, the Middle Eastern man, emerges. After a furtive glance around, he quickly takes a seat. Now Colter makes the connection. The bomb in the restroom The Middle Eastern man emerging from the same restroom. Colter starts down the long aisle. In his seat, Guzman slips on dark glasses. He looks forbidding with his mustache and olive-colored skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going? Colter stands in front of him, arms crossed. Behind his d glasses, Guzman ignores him, but he's visibly uncomfortab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name? Guzman is stock still. Beads of sweat on his forehead. Th conductor appears, accosting Colter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you to take a seat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin? Where are you? It's over. I found him. Appealing to Goodwin's invisible presence. But nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to? An edgy silence. Other passengers looking over. Colter's about to retort, about to accuse Guzman, when he stops. It's too easy. Colter senses the uproar he's about to create. Which just might be a mistake. He reconsiders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. This guy seemed a little... anxious. I was worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am minding my business. Tell him to mind his.
The conductor has noticed Guzman's white-knuckle uneasine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feeling all right, sir? With a pained smile, Guzman loosens his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motion sickness, I'm afraid. I believe I will get off at the next stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. The conductor turns back to Colter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm sitting down. Turning away, he finds a seat. He studies Guzman out of t corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now approaching Newark Station. Newark Station, next stop. The train begins to slow down. Several rows up, he sees Christina. She looks back at him with distaste. A small number of passengers get up, among them the Colle Student. He catches Colter's attention as he picks up a WALLET from a seat and catches up with Derek, the Stock Broker, who's about to get off the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you dropped this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved, takes back the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Thanks. The College Student waits to get off. Colter now eyes him closely. As the train pulls to a stop, Guzman forcefully pushes forward towards the doors, moving with a barely contained urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Please let me through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, he's running away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors slide open.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Newark Station. The Old Man, Derek and the College Kid get off. Guzman hurries past them towards the station house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All aboard. Doors are closing. Just before the doors close, Colter steps out onto the platform. Eyes locked on Guzman -- who disappears inside station house. The train PULLS OFF, leaving Colter behind. Did he make t right move? As he goes to pursue Guzman, Colter is struck by more sen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STATION CLOCK. Its digital numerals flash 7:50 a.m., hurting Colter's eyes with their brightness. The dying HISS of the rails as the train recedes down the track. The super-sharp glint of a PENNY embedded down in the gra of the tracks. The melancholy SIGH of trees in the wind. Pushing it all aside, he hurries after Guzman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering, Colter stops. There's no sign of Guzman. Just a empty marble lobby. A lone CLERK restocks timetable brochures at a display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy just came through here. Did you see where he went?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Lots of guys come through here. Windows look out over the station's parking lot. There's sign of Guzman out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just here. A Middle Eastern- looking guy. Through the platform doors comes Derek, followed by the College Kid. Derek heads for the parking lot, while the College Kid mills around the newspaper stand. A muffled COUGH. Colter spins. Sees a door marked "MEN'S ROOM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing open the door, Colter discovers a row of 1930's-e sinks and stalls. An intercom crackles to life:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The train to Philadelphia will be four minutes late... The train to Philadelphia will be four minutes late... Colter's footsteps echo down the length of the deserted m room. The last stall door is SHUT. From within the closed stall, comes the sound of VOMITING Colter edges closer. A toilet FLUSHES. Guzman emerges from the stall. Looks awful. Freezes when he sees Colter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All better now? Guzman's face hardens. He goes to the sink to wash his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't much care for trains myself.

The bathroom mirror, of course, reflects back Sean Fentre face, not Colter's. Guzman does not seem to notice this disparity. He picks up his briefcase and briskly walks ou Colter takes an uneasy look at Fentress looking back at h in the mirror, then follows Guzman out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colter emerges in the lobby. Guzman is nearby. A bit indecisive. Colter wanders over to the newspaper stand. The STATION CLOCK reads 7:54 a.m. Colter looks down at HIS WATCH: THREE MINUTES remaining. What will Guzman do? Guzman glances over at Colter, then heads through the doo and back out on the train platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guzman sits on a bench. Colter stops nearby him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I resent this. This is harassment. You obviously work for someone. FBI. CIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expected this reception in your country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you going to pull this off? That bomb has a cell phone detonator. And I don't see a pay phone around here. So I'm betting you got a phone on you with the number already programmed in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you're talking about. I am an international business man. An executive. The tracks begin to VIBRATE. In the distance comes the HO of an EXPRESS TRAIN approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open your briefcase. Prove to me there's no phone in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will prove nothing to you. Leave me alone. WHAM! Colter PUNCHES Guzman with tremendous force, sendin Guzman sprawling to the ground. Colter's hand throbs from the force of the punch. The simulation's reality stuns Colter all over again. Crouching down, Colter pops open Guzman's briefcase. Insi is a corporate IDENTIFICATION BADGE with Guzman's name an photograph on it. The company is Shell Oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Hasnan Guzman, Vice President, Shell Oil." Must be a cover.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Philadelphia train now approaching. Guzman groans in pain. Colter rifles through his briefcas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell's your phone? Another look at HIS WATCH -- 20 SECONDS. Grabbing Guzman, Colter goes through his suit pockets. He triumphantly pulls out GUZMAN'S CELL PHONE and steps back Guzman looks up at him, eyes moist with humiliation and malice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. Now let's see you try to -- A distant THUD rattles the station windows. Colter pivots looks down the tracks. The first thing he sees is

dialogues.speaker: THE EXPRESS TRAIN
dialogues.text: Closing in on the station. The second thing he sees, far beyond it, miles further do the tracks, is the RISING PLUME of a HUGE EXPLOSION. Colter looks back at Guzman in shock. Then down at Guzman cell phone. Which has remained off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't do it. Disbelief. As the din of the distant explosion is drowned out by the ROAR of

dialogues.speaker: THE ARRIVING EXPRESS TRAIN
dialogues.text: With a cry of rage Guzman SPRINGS UP and PUSHES COLTER IN THE PATH OF THE ON-COMING EXPRESS TRAIN -- with a blast o its horn, THE TRAIN RUNS HIM OVER. Everything stops. Like film celluloid catching fire in a projector, the wor itself BLISTERS AND BURNS INTO SEARING WHITE... into smothering, forgetful SILENCE... For exactly 2/3 of a second (1/3 of a second longer than before), the same flickering after-image appears:

dialogues.speaker: THIN LINES
dialogues.text: This time they all connect into THE SPOKES OF A WHEEL. A BICYCLE WHEEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of MACHINERY STRAINING. Colter is SLAMMED back into his seat -- back in the capsule. All he can do is ha on and gasp for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy fuck!

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stabilize. Lower your pulse. Colter opens his eyes. He's back in his military flight suit. The craft goes still. Cautiously, he releases his hands f their grip on the seat restraints. He looks like he's sweated off five pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need to urinate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fucking train just ran over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need to urinate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing this? Am I on some kind of drug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find the bomber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't find the bomber. You fooled me with the Middle Eastern guy. I went for the diversion. What kind of freaky simulation is this? Let me out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Middle Eastern guy? Be specific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guzman. Shell Oil. Look, I don't have intel experience. Why do you have me doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already been told what you need to know. Discipline your memory. Limit your operational awareness to the tasks we assign you. Everything else is irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irrelevant? Killing me each time is irrelevant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not die. As you can see, you simply return to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? How can you do that? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the man with the pipe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a man smoking a pipe. I saw him on the monitor. Who's he? How does he fit into this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man with the pipe isn't here right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him. This isn't right. I'm not your prisoner. Goodwin makes technical adjustments to dials and gauges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel unsatisfied with our relationship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Why are you talking like that? Is this some kind of script?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Guzman, the Middle Eastern man, is innocent, as you maintain, who might be the guilty party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? I'm tired of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a game, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what is it? Don't you already know who the bomber is? Don't you have all the answers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no answers. Only corpses. A weird beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corpses? Whose corpses? The passengers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some were too badly burned to be identified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heat from the explosion fused many of them completely into the wreckage. Is this the truth? Or another evasive answer? His mind pulled in all kinds of unpleasant directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were real people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This really happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today?! The train blew up today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was attacked this morning, at 7:57 a.m., Eastern Standard Time. Six miles outside of New York City. Colter's head is spinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying. I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do your senses tell you? His senses tell him it's true. But how can he accept it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I, right now, as we speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Beleaguered Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My unit's still in Iraq. I'm flying missions in Iraq. I flew one yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your unit was rotated Stateside three weeks ago. The news comes like a slap in the face. Colter clearly ha no memory of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do I still have Iraqi dirt underneath my fingernails? Goodwin simply makes another adjustment on the controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me! Three weeks? I've been back three weeks? How'd I get in here? Have I seen my family? Does my father know I'm home? "Cause I'd kinda like to tell him if that's the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up, soldier. Goodwin hunches forward, putting his elbows on his desk. he does so, he inadvertently reveals a glimpse of his military unit SHOULDER PATCH. The insignia contains wings and a lightning bolt against a background of stars. Underneath it is written "CAOC-N."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is just the beginning. Our intel says there are more attacks are coming today. And they're linked with the train. Time is of the essence. Do you understand? Colter barely hears. He's fixated on that shoulder patch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D.N.I. Counterterrorism has come up with the five most likely follow-up targets in the New York area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are, in no order of importance, the Holland Tunnel, Newark International Airport, the Brooklyn Bridge, Penn Station and the Empire State Building. It could be any of them, it could be none of them. Whatever it is, if you find the bomber and learn his plan, the next one we might be in a position to prevent. Those are your orders. It's too much information to process. Colter's head spins with questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. If I'm somehow on that train before it blows up, why don't I just dismantle the bomb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are not your orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But all those people dying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are not your orders. You are not to influence events any more than you need to in order to accomplish your mission. Military priorities. Defying comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't volunteer for this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see the release form you signed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know it's real? How do I know you didn't force me to sign it? And how the hell can I be put on a train over and over again -- a train I never was really on?! He might as well be talking to a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in time travel, Goodwin. There's no such thing.
Machinery begins to RUN. Like the WHINE of a JET ENGINE firing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one way forward, Captain. Seventeen minutes. Find the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why seventeen? Why me? Why anything? The capsule begins to SHAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out! Don't send me back there! SFX: UP ON a HUGE ROAR as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TRAIN hurls down the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Landscape flies by. Colter's forehead rests against the glass window. Piercing sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. This is not happening. He leans back in his seat, as if just another beaten down office worker on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't life grand? Across from him, Christina sketching. A gentle smirk. He focuses in on her. Not knowing where else to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You an artist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to art school. Doesn't make me an artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see what you're working on?
Her pencil pauses. She eyes Colter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not. He looks down at his watch. 7:41 a.m. He's been back for one minute. Adjusting the settings, he changes the digita display to COUNT DOWN the remaining SIXTEEN MINUTES. He tries again for human contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look like you belong here. The way you're dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd really like to see what you're working on. Unless you're worried I won't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's private. And your opinion doesn't interest me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you scribble away on that thing so as not to deal with people. She scowls. Tosses the sketch pad onto his lap. Surprised Colter opens it. It's full of faces -- thumbnail portrait of other passengers riding the train. They're exquisitely observed, darkly stylized into expressions of loneliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go that far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, they're really good, Miss...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Colter. How many of these passengers have you drawn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them, practically. She leans forward, eyes glinting conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know all about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a collector of moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman over there? She's a patent attorney with three kids and a summer place on Long Island. More important, however, she colors her hair herself and wears the same houndstooth check suit every third Wednesday. The nebbishy fellow behind her always calls into his office three minutes before we go into the tunnel. And the guy with the shaved head and leather jacket eating a scone has a profile identical to that of Julius Caesar. A click of the restroom door opening. Guzman emerges from the bathroom and returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that guy? Christina looks over Guzman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen him before today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cranky. Thinks the worst of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see anything unusual happen this morning? Anything out of the ordinary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anyone else come out of that bathroom that you remember? She takes a closer look at him. A puzzled smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Colter hesitates. Debating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know? Haven't you seen me here every day for, what, three months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's different about you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you that there's a terrorist on this train, that I was sent here to catch him, would you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most fervently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell me which one you'd arrest. Christina pages through her sketch pad again. Considering different faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all so utterly normal. That's what's terrifying about them. Perhaps there's more than one. A team at work. The patent attorney in cahoots with Julius Caesar and the nebbishy guy. And don't forget the sullen college kid. He's the expendable one. But they're all controlled by this good- looking stock broker. She shows him her sketch of Derek, the Stock Broker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blond, blue eyed, hyper alert. The perfect Machiavellian operative. Out for himself. He'll betray them all in the end. She's not taking him seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. He gets up. Foolish of him to confide in her. His watch n reads THIRTEEN MINUTES.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now approaching Newark Station. Newark Station, next stop. The train begins to slow. Derek, Guzman, the Old Man and College Kid head towards the exit doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's getting away...! Colter moves aside to let them walk past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am? How old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Thirty two? Her icy glare tells him he's guessed too high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The disembarking passengers exit the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is moving again. In the exit area, Colter watch the station disappear. He's doing this all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next stop New York Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two screws rattle in the sink. Colter gazes up at the half-opened ventilation shaft -- and at the edge of the sinister bomb planted there. Back down to the mirror. Sean Fentress's face. The most baffling mystery of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Fentress? Who are you? How can I be you? FLASHCUT -- Back in the isolation unit. On the monitor, t glimpse of Goodwin's SHOULDER PATCH INSIGNIA. The unit initials "CAOC-N." Back to scene. Colter churning over the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "CAOC-N." What unit is that? A KNOCK on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windows comes the blur of the EXPRESS TRAIN whizzing past (the same train which previously ran over Colter). Emerging from the bathroom, Colter discovers Christina th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who were you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone. Colter walks off. Irked at his change in tone, she follow him, carrying his messenger bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure, okay? It's just that you left your bag on your seat. (trying to be cute) It's a flagrant violation of rail security, leaving a suspicious package behind and all that. Maybe you're the terrorist. This is too much. Colter turns on her. Paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrorist? Why did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop joking. Who are you? Are you an operative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea you were so thoroughly weird. I'm not entirely sure I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have sketches of everybody on board? Are you part of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can have you arrested. Maybe that's the only way you'll drop the bullshit and talk. Stay put. I'm getting help. She sees he's serious and drops her arch playfulness. Spe in a flat, sober voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I? I'll tell you. I'm twenty seven years old. I have no savings and no health insurance. He turns back. Waits. The more she speaks, the angrier sh gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months ago I moved back in with my parents because I ran out of money. I got A's in line drawing and advanced oil painting but no one's buying my stuff. Two weeks ago I put away all my paints. My little sketch book is the last thing left. You see, I'm not a artist. I'm a receptionist in a law firm. The only thing I operate is a phone switchboard.
The stark reality of her life. The HORN of the FREIGHT TRAIN yanks his attention to the windows. Up ahead are the row houses opposite which the train exploded. Time is running down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me tell you about you. You work at the New York Public Library. You've been eyeing me for months on this train but haven't said a word to me. You're bland and colorless and predictable. And now I see you're delusional, too. Colter doesn't hear her. He's still looking out the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the row houses, a COMMERCIAL AIRLINER is climbing serenely into the blue after take-off out of Newark Airpo The view is wiped away as the FREIGHT TRAIN comes surging past the windows. But the sight of the plane has already caused something to click in Colter's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. "CAOC-N." That's not army. That's Air Force. Combined Air and Space Operations Center. Nellis Air Force Base!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you mocking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're running this whole thing out of Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada. Fucking Nevada! Tears in Christina's eyes. That Colter would persist in t delusion after what she's confessed about herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (racking his brain) What's there? What's on that base? B-52s. KC tankers. Air Combat Command. Predator Drones. Remote operations. (something to this) This a remote operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it is time travel?
A worried CONDUCTOR runs past them, talking rapidly into radio. We catch the words "bomb threat."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say? A WARNING ALARM begins beeping. Passengers look around uneasily. Christina, however, focuses her anger on Colter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor. Don't ever talk to me again. She drops his messenger bag at his feet and walks away. Colter looks down at his watch. THE LAST SECONDS TICK AWA 5... 4... 3...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christina! He grabs her -- she struggles against him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off me! But he HOLDS HER TIGHT, shielding her with his body and squeezing his eyes shut as --

dialogues.speaker: THE EXPLOSION RIPS THROUGH THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: Blinding light. Painful to look at. Like a star exploding. A dull, hollow sound of WIND rattling through an abyss. And then the ghostly still life. Details flicker into vie A bicycle. A stone wall. And next to it... A woman. It's Christina. Turning to look at us. A gentle, reassuri smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click -- click. Click -- click. The video monitor is malfunctioning. It flickers on and off, revealing Colter' face in and out of darkness.
The capsule is nearly shut down. The controls appear non- functional. Ice crystals have formed over the circuitry. Colter hugs himself, shivering. His breath is visible in capsule's tomb-like cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin? What's happening? Come in. Can you read me? It's goddamn cold in here. He hits a few buttons. Almost at random. The VENTS which had been blowing in air FALL SILENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin, I'm losing oxygen. The monitor fizzles out. The light from the controls FADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodwin! It's now COMPLETELY DARK. He BANGS on the side of the capsule. Just a muffled thump A terrifying silence. The SNAP of a harness releasing. A THUD as Colter falls t the floor of the capsule. Cursing. Some sounds of thrashi around. Then... The SPARK of a BLUE FLARE illuminates Colter's face. He's activated a miniature signal light on his flight suit. It begins to BLINK. Like a beacon for downed pilots afloat i the sea. It is the only light in the otherwise dead capsu Up on his knees, he grasps the release handles of the EXI HATCH. Using all his strength he TURNS... But the handles don't budge. The hatch remains sealed. He gets to his feet. Can't stand up fully. The capsule is incredibly cramped. Rifling through a cabinet, he discovers OPERATIONAL MANUA in small, almost illegible type. And a small set of TOOLS He spreads them out on the tiny ledge. Taking a wrench, h BANGS on the escape hatch. A deep, clanging ECHO in the hull.

So, like any pilot would, he sets about repairing his cra At first he puzzles over the electronics and circuitry. Daunted by the complexity. There's no time to lose. Using a miniature screw driver, begins unscrewing the monitor panel. His fingers are slow and clumsy in the frigid cold and the screw driver slips of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Icicles have appeared over dormant air vents. Colter, ice crystals in his hair, is shivering more violently. Much o the capsule's electronics lay open and exposed. Using copper wires, he's attempting to revive a row of BATTERIES. They spark once... twice... Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Another SPARK. It shocks him. There's a puff of blue smok He's burned his fingers. But the battery now has a tiny BLINKING GREEN LIGHT. Working fast, Colter attaches the copper wires to the lea on the battery. From inside the engines comes a faint electric HUM. FFFT. The monitor awakens. Like a film projector it throw the image of a PLAYING CARD onto the opposite side of the craft. Colter begins replacing the monitor components. As he doe a pre-recorded AUDIO FILE comes on:

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- four principle dialects of Arabic: Egyptian, Gulf, Syrian- Lebanese and North African. We will now play you portions of each, discussing the audible differences between them. CLIPS of SPOKEN ARABIC begin to play. Colter continues reconstituting the computer. The monitor fills with scrolling lines of COMPUTER CODE. With an oddly low-tech CLANG, the heart of the machine reawakens. The air vents come back to life. Heat starts t return. The icicles begin to DRIP.

Colter sits back in his seat, exhausted from the work. The monitor switches to a real-time view of the LAB. Goodwin's chair is there, but Goodwin is not in sight. In background distorted by the FISH-EYE LENS, various technicians wander by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Anyone out there? It's me. He toggles an audio jack. Then a MAN comes walking up. Frowns into the camera, as if through the foggy lens of another world. It's the MAN WITH THE PIPE. The elusive Bohemian scientis whom Colter glimpsed once before. He will be known as RUTLEDGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? Rutledge is tinkering with the camera. The image shakes f a moment as he adjusts it. Then puts on a headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Project designer initiating sequence and drives check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here! I'm okay! Rutledge checks his headset. Not sure he heard right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's me. Colter. Rutledge blinks in surprise. The blue eyes sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! It's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The capsule lost power. It's still pretty cold in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been working towards you from the other side. Nice to have you with us again. You feeling all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Rutledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't let me talk to you before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. They're pretty anal around here. (lights his pipe) Don't tell them you saw me smoking in here, okay? His genial eccentricity is completely at odds with the military environment. And then it occurs to Colter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the inventor of this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer the term project designer. And sorry for all the secrecy. Goodwin will be thrilled you re- established contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to deal with Goodwin anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? He's torturing me. I'm helpless. Can't you get me out of here? Rutledge looks uneasy. As a scientist, he's ill-equipped deal with personnel issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Goodwin have it in for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a remote operator. And remote operators are risk averse pussies who sit at control screens in the rear while actual pilots like me put their asses on the line in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems pretty devoted to the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just what kind of mission is this? Talk to me, man. Why won't he let me save those people on the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they can't be saved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I know what's going to happen. I could take apart the bomb. Stop the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but you'd be doing it in the Source Code, not here. Not in our own past. Mystery upon mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I should be telling you this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telling me what? Coaxing the scientist in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quantum physics. Linear algebra. Parabolic calculus. It would take weeks to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Source Code time travel?
Rutledge sighs. Looks at his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I save those people on the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it like this: events in our past can never be undone. Einstein proved that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Source Code opens up another past for you. A parallel past. It looks the same but it has no intersection with our own world. In essence, by sending you back, an entirely new but utterly parallel world is created. It looks identical to ours, but nothing you do there has any effect on this reality. At last some useful information. Colter races to process

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to the Source Code world after I leave it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You can never know that because you're not there to observe it. Maybe it vanishes. Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should tell them you're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see it each time. Right after the bomb goes off. Like an after image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bicycle and a stone wall and a girl. It's a girl from the train. I don't know where any of it is supposed to be, but -- Rutledge removes the pipe from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. You see all this after you leave the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just for a split second. Rutledge is stunned. Like he's discovered some strange ne property to his invention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me you're not making this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's there. What do you think it means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Rutledge looks off camera for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here. There's no more time to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure he sends you back in. Find out about the after images. Goodwin appears. Rutledge reluctantly takes off his heads

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rutledge, wait. Don't leave me. Rutledge steps away. A pointed look at Colter. Goodwin settles back into his seat, donning the headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alive. No thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find the bomber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a brick wall, Goodwin. A fucking brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower your pulse. The situation has worsened. The fire on the tracks caused one of the freight cars to blow up and release some kind of gas. As a precaution they're having to evacuate all of lower Manhattan. Evacuate lower Manhattan? The enormity of this. Having to take it on faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may have lost the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Let's keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were expecting more from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you more. Let me think for a second. But Goodwin ignores him. Absorbed in paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freight car blows up from the fire. It spews gas, or what could be gas -- it might be chlorine, so they can't take any chances. Anxious now. Trying to make up lost ground. Whatever it takes to get sent back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they decide to play it safe and evacuate parts of New York City. And maybe that's part of the terrorists' plan, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... so who benefits from that? What's vulnerable? What's down there in lower Manhattan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall Street.
Surprising himself with this insight. And now Goodwin is paying attention again. Waiting for mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wall Street. That's what they're going to hit next. The financial markets. Goodwin considers this. For the first time, slightly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVERS LICENSE PHOTOS
dialogues.text: The video monitor shows CHRISTINA's DMV shot. Her wry, secretive smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she die, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. This drivers license photo was found with her body. We're creating a database of recovered identifications as they come in from the site. A pang of sorrow. Moving among ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure she's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see her morgue photos?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was sitting across from me.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We know.
Playing a GRAINY, HAND-HELD VIDEO of the TRAIN WRECKAGE. Rescue workers in protective gear picking their way caref through the twisted, charred remains of the two trains.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This was taken shortly after the rescue crews arrived on scene. The TIME CODE on the image reads 8:26 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We noted the location of each corpse when we pulled it out. On screen, rescue workers pull a CHARRED CORPSE out of th wreckage.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Prepare yourself. This is unedited footage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I didn't want to see her! The camera ZOOMS IN on a corpse. Its burned face, like a piece of rotted fruit, fills the screen. Nevertheless, we recognize it. And it's not Christina. It's someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's...

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sean Fentress. The man in the mirror. Himself, at least on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He died on the train.

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As a host identity, Sean Fentress had to have certain basic similarities to you. Gender. Blood type. Approximate age. His head was still intact. We need the head, you see. To link the two of you remotely. They carry the corpse towards a MORGUE TRUCK with a vast array of SATELLITE COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT attached to it
The image freezes, then DISSOLVES back to Christina's DMV photo. Silence. Pondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see the other passenger photos? Perhaps that would help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still have Christina's body? The other things she was carrying?

dialogues.speaker: GOODWIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know about her. Everything I can. She's not just another victim. She's connected to all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rich smell of steaming coffee. The glint of a polishe leather shoe. The crisp click of someone uncapping a fountain pen. The scenery rushing by -- the blur of trees the soft lavender of the morning sky. The swell and pull the mighty machine coursing over the rails. If a train ride could ever be a sensory delight, this is To Colter, every sensation has become even more pronounce more intensely real than ever. CLOSE ON - HIS WATCH - A beep as he sets it to countdown again from seventeen minutes. The duration of his freedom Across from him is Christina. Absorbed with her sketching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty six dollars and eleven cents. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your wallet. Right now. Thirty six dollars and eleven cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a magic trick or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. In five seconds, a guy's going to open a can of soda. 4... 3.. 2... 1...

dialogues.speaker: CHK-THOCK
dialogues.text: The Overweight Man opens his soda can. She gives Colter a quizzical look. He points out the window. They're passing neighborhood of modest homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're about to pass a street with willow trees. Two girls will be jumping rope. A white dog's going to run out behind them. A Dalmatian mix. In a moment, they pass a scene exactly as Colter describe Christina's befuddled smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to tell me how you're doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close observation. You could say I'm a collector of moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A collector of moments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the cheesiest line I've ever heard. She resumes her drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trained to be an artist. No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got A's in line drawing and oil painting. But your work didn't sell. You took a job answering phones in a law firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months ago you moved back in with your parents. Two weeks ago you put your paints away for good. The sketch book is all you have left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? Who have you been talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? No. I haven't ever talked to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have, Christina. You've drawn all these people here. You know their routines. At one point you thought you were different from all of them. But now you're not so sure. Christina has gone white. Utterly incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small bar area. Coffee sloshing in styrofoam cups Colte hands one to Christina and sits down opposite her. A glan at his watch shows TWELVE MINUTES left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you've got my attention. Now tell me what this is all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you selling something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I can't use up any more time trying to convince you. I just need you to believe everything I'm about to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear with me. (beat, where to begin?) Your sketch book. Is there a drawing of me in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Christina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, fine! Here. She flips through it. Shows him a sketch of SEAN FENTRESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, that's not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a little credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You drew what you saw, but the person you're seeing now is someone else. I'm not Sean Fentress. I'm not really on this train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not really on this train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking someone's place. Borrowing it. My name is Colter. I'm a soldier. And I'm being held prisoner. And this is the only way -- the only time and place I have -- to figure out how to escape. She gives him a blank look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After three months of riding the train, this is how you introduce yourself to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Elements in the American military are using me for an experiment. I'm not sure exactly how it all happened, but I'm at a facility on Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada. Right now. As we speak. It's a project called Source Code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Source Code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a program. It shifts identities. It also performs small amounts of time travel. Or "time engineering." I don't know the jargon. He's not getting through to her. It's too bizarre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been put on this train to look for someone. A criminal. And I need to find out just enough about him to keep them putting me back on this train. Because right here's only place I can figure out what's really happening. But I have very little time. And each time I come back, you won't remember me and I'll have to go through this all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, I think, deliciously mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do I know all those things about you if we've never spoken before? She doesn't have an answer. Can't easily dismiss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why tell all this to me? There's lots of people around for you to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think you have the answer to this whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I don't have the answer for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a vision. I keep having it. It's very powerful. And you're in it. And there's a bicycle. And this... old stone wall. And it's very peaceful. Does this sound familiar? Like where you live, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stone walls? My parents live in a house with aluminum siding and an American eagle over the door. The only bike is a Harley which the guy down the street revs at three in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vision must mean something. It's the only time when I'm not on the train or in the capsule. Why else would Rutledge be so interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Rutledge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who was trying to help me understand something. Until they got to him. He lowers his head. A dead end. No answer. The train begins to slow down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now approaching Newark Station. Newark Station, next stop. Colter looks at HIS WATCH. Ten minutes left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a program on TV. It was about psychics. They say psychics have a lot of paranoia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in that shit.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Newark Station. Through the window, the Old Man, Derek and the College Ki disembark. Guzman hurries past them to the station house.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All aboard. Doors are closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have people you can go to for help? Friends, family? The train begins to move again.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a New York bound train. Next stop, New York - Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of my friends are in the military. My dad runs a melon farm in Alabama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
